give.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
give.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Most people are willing to give to charity.
The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.
What did Bob give you for your birthday?
Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.
I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.
a ring which was given to him by his mother
I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!
give.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to put something in someone’s hand
give.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He poured some wine into a glass and gave it to her.
give.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to allow or make it possible for someone to do something
give.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: She was given absolute control over all recruitment decisions.
He finally gave us permission  to leave.
These meetings give everyone a chance to express their opinions.
Students are given the freedom to choose their own topics.
Language gives us the ability to communicate at a much higher level than any other animal.
Women were given the vote in the early 1900s.
This bill will give more power to local authorities.
give.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to tell someone information or details about something, or to tell someone what they should do
give.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: She gave me some information on university courses.
My secretary will be able to give you more details.
Let me give you some advice.
Can you give me directions to the station (=tell me how to go there)?
You may have to give evidence in court  (=tell a court about what you have seen or know to be true).
They were given strict instructions not to tell anyone.
He gave a disturbing account of the murder.
give.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to do something by making a movement with your hand, face, body etc
give.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Joel gave me a smile as I walked in.
He gave her a big hug.
He gave a wave of his hand.
Don’t move until I give the signal.
She picked up the envelope and gave it a shake.
give.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to make a speech, perform a piece of music etc for a group of people
give.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: He’s giving a talk on early Roman pottery.
They gave one of their best performances to date.
give.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to make someone have a feeling
give.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Keep the noise down – you’re giving me a headache!
He gave us quite a shock.
The course has given me a lot more confidence.
His job did not give him much sense of fulfilment.
Their music has given pleasure to a lot of people over the years.
give.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The new software has given us quite a few problems.
give.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to infect someone with the same illness that you have
give.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Don’t come too close – I don’t want you to give me your cold!
It’s very unlikely a doctor could give HIV to a patient.
give.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to organize a social event such as a party
give.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: We’re giving a small party for dad’s birthday next week.
give.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to tell someone to do a job or piece of work
give.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: How much homework are you given in a week?
He’s always giving us chores to do around the house.
give.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to make someone or something have a particular quality
give.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: The ginger gives the dish a wonderful spicy flavour.
His grey hair gave him an air of distinction.
Its association with the movie industry has given the place a certain glamor.
give.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to pay a particular amount of money for something
give.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: They say they’re not willing to give any more than they’ve already offered.
They gave us £700 for our old car.
How much will you give me for these two games?
give.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to behave towards someone in a way that shows you have a particular attitude or feeling towards them
give.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: The people were expected to give their leader absolute obedience and loyalty.
give.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to officially say that someone must have a particular punishment
give.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: If you don’t pay on time, you could be given a fine of up to $1,000.
The judge gave her two years in prison.
give somebody six months/three years etc
give.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: to be willing to change what you think or do according to what else happens
give.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: I think that both sides need to give a little.
give.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: to state what your official decision or judgment is, for example in a game
give.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: The referee has given a penalty.
The jury will be giving its verdict within the next couple of days.
give.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: to decide that someone should have a particular score or mark for something that they have done
give.translation[0].definitions[17].exam: She only gave me a B for my last essay.
The judges have given him top marks for this performance.
give.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: if a material gives, it bends or stretches when you put pressure on it
give.translation[0].definitions[18].exam: New shoes often feel tight, but the leather should give a little after a few days.
give.translation[0].definitions[19].defi: if something gives, it breaks or moves away suddenly because of weight or pressure on it
give.translation[0].definitions[19].exam: The branch suddenly gave beneath him.
I pushed against the door with all my might, but it still wouldn’t give.
give.translation[0].definitions[20].defi: if a woman gives herself to a man, she has sex with him
give.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to let someone have something, without expecting to be paid for it
He was always giving me gifts.
They gave a free drink to all their customers.
donate
to give money to an organization that helps people or protects something, or to give your blood or part of your body to save someone’s life
The company donates 1 per cent of its profits to charity.
70% of people wanted to donate their organs after death.
award
to officially give money or a prize to someone
She was awarded a million dollars in damages.
Hollywood awarded him an Oscar for his performance.
present
to formally or officially give something to someone by putting it in their hands, especially at a formal ceremony
They presented her with a bouquet of flowers.
to officially arrange for someone to have something that you own after your death
He left most of his property to his wife.
lavish somebody with something/lavish something on somebody
to give someone a lot of something, especially praise, attention, or gifts
After his team won, the press lavished him with praise.
confer
to give someone an honour, a university degree, or the right or power to do something
the powers conferred on him by Parliament
the highest honor that her country could confer on her
bestow
to give someone something to show how much they are respected, for example an honour, a title, or a gift – a very formal use
He was also bestowed the title of ‘Cultural Ambassador of Grenada’.
to give something to a group of people
hand something out/give something out
to give something to each of the people in a group
The teacher handed out the test papers.
I’m going to give out some forms for you to fill in.
distribute
to give things to a large number of people, especially in the streets
Anti-war protesters were distributing leaflets.
share
to divide something into equal parts and give a part to each person
They shared the profits among the staff.
give.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the ability of a material or substance to bend or stretch when put under pressure
give.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The rope has quite a bit of give in it.
